justification: SLE commonly presents with lymphopenia, hemolytic anemia, and alopecia. The alopecia in SLE is typically nonscarring.}, {diagnosis: Evans syndrome

justification: Evans syndrome is characterized by the combination of autoimmune hemolytic anemia and immune thrombocytopenia (ITP). Lymphopenia can also be seen in some cases.}, {diagnosis: Drug-induced lupus
justification: Certain medications can induce a lupus-like syndrome that can cause lymphopenia, hemolytic anemia, and alopecia.}, {diagnosis: Aplastic anemia

justification: Aplastic anemia is a rare but serious condition that affects the bone marrow, leading to a deficiency in all blood cell types, including lymphocytes, red blood cells, and platelets.}, {diagnosis: HIV infection
justification: HIV infection can cause a range of hematological abnormalities, including lymphopenia, anemia, and alopecia.}, {diagnosis: Severe viral infections

justification: Certain viral infections, such as Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) and cytomegalovirus (CMV), can suppress the immune system and cause lymphopenia, anemia, and hair loss.}, {diagnosis: Lymphoma
justification: Lymphoma is a cancer of the lymphatic system that can involve the bone marrow and cause a decrease in blood cell counts.}, {diagnosis: Chemotherapy-induced cytopenia

justification: Chemotherapy drugs are known to suppress the bone marrow, leading to a decrease in blood cell counts, including lymphopenia, anemia, and hair loss.}, {diagnosis: Radiation therapy-induced cytopenia
justification: Radiation therapy, similar to chemotherapy, can damage the bone marrow and cause a decrease in blood cell counts.}, {diagnosis: Nutritional deficiencies
justification: Severe deficiencies in certain nutrients, such as iron, vitamin B12, and folate, can affect blood cell production and lead to anemia, lymphopenia, and hair loss.}
